title: AB 1534
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature declares the importance of county assessors following state laws for consistent assessment practices. They aim to protect taxpayers by ensuring certified staff make decisions on property exemptions and ownership changes efficiently. Education and certification requirements will be implemented with the advice of the State Board of Equalization. Section 674 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to require competitive bids for appraisal work contracts. Contractors must maintain confidentiality of assessee information as per specified sections. A contractor requesting information from an assessee must have written authorization from the assessor. They cannot share appraisal data with assessors from other counties. After the contract ends, the contractor must not retain any confidential information and must return it within 90 days. The contractor must purge and return any assessee records, provide a written declaration of compliance, and include specific language in contracts as prescribed by the State Board of Equalization. A contractor is defined as a person not employed by the state, county, or city who performs appraisal work under contract with an assessor. Additionally, a new Article 8.5 is added to the Revenue and Taxation Code regarding Assessment Analyst Certificates. Article 8.5 (Section 674) in the Revenue and Taxation Code requires assessors to hold a valid assessment analyst certificate for making decisions on changes in ownership and property tax exemptions. The board administers examinations for assessment analyst certificates, in collaboration with the Department of Human Resources. Applicants must pass the exam to demonstrate competency in making ownership change or exemption decisions. Applicants denied a certificate have the right to a review under the Administrative Procedure Act. Applicants denied a certificate have the right to a review under the Administrative Procedure Act. The board does not charge fees for examinations, certifications, or training. Certified assessment analysts must complete 24 hours of board-approved training annually to maintain their certificate, with excess training hours carrying over for up to three years. The board requires certified assessment analysts to complete annual training to maintain their certificate. Failure to complete training may result in certificate revocation. Advanced assessment analyst certificates are issued to applicants with at least three years of experience who have completed advanced study or passed an advanced examination. The board requires advanced assessment analysts to complete an advanced course of study or pass an advanced examination. They must also complete 12 hours of training annually to maintain their certificate, with excess training hours carrying over for up to two years. Failure to complete required training may lead to revocation of the advanced assessment analyst certificate, with proceedings conducted according to the Administrative Procedure Act. Training for certificate retention includes staying updated on case law, statutory law, and administrative rules. Applicants must disclose financial interests in legal entities at certification and annually thereafter. Each applicant must disclose their financial interest in any legal entity at certification and annually thereafter. If required to file with the Fair Political Practices Commission, a duplicate filing will suffice. The board may issue a temporary certificate to a newly elected or appointed assessor or a newly employed person in the county assessor's office for up to one year to allow them to take an examination. The certificate cannot be renewed. The board may issue an interim certificate to a current assessor or county assessor office employee for up to four years to allow them to take an examination. The certificate cannot be renewed. Noncertificated staff can assist with exemption applications and ownership documents but cannot make decisions. This article applies in counties that have passed a resolution to require certification as provided.
